title-group.article-title: Interpretation of Chinese overt and null embedded arguments by English-speaking learners

author-notes.corresp: Lucy Xia Zhao, School of East Asian Studies, University of Sheffield, 6/8 Shearwood Road, Sheffield, S10 2TD, UK Email: lucy.zhao@sheffield.ac.uk

abstract.p: It has been proposed that external interfaces are vulnerable to residue optionality, whereas pure syntax and internal interfaces are acquirable in second language (L2) acquisition (Sorace, 2005, 2011; Sorace and Filiaci, 2006). The proposal was tested in this article through the interpretation of overt and null embedded arguments in L2 Chinese grammars. The article identifies two types of null elements in Chinese: Øziji and Øtopic. Øziji is a purely syntactic category, whereas Øtopic is a syntax–discourse interface category. Being a D-pronoun, ta ‘he/him’ can refer to either the matrix subject or a discourse entity in the embedded argument position. Its interpretation involves lexicon–syntax and syntax–semantics internal interfaces. Results from a picture judgment task showed that external interfaces were acquired as well as pure syntax and internal interfaces, which supports the claims of Ivanov, 2009; Iverson et al., 2008; Kraš, 2008; Rothman, 2007, 2009; Slabakova and Ivanov, 2011. In addition, Øtopic was acquired at different states in different sentence positions. This supports the claim that interface categories should not be considered holistically (Yuan, 2010). The article further speculates that cross-linguistic influence and the nature of the possible positive evidence may have contributed to the difference here in terms of representation and/or processing.

sec.title: I Introduction
sec.p: The interface categories have been researched extensively in recent second language (L2) studies. Some researchers propose that while L2 learners have no trouble acquiring categories that are internal to the computational system of syntax proper and those that belong to internal interfaces such as the syntax–semantics and lexicon–syntax interfaces, categories that involve an external interface such as the syntax–discourse interface are vulnerable to residual optionality (see, amongst others, Sorace, 2005; Sorace and Filiaci, 2006). This proposal is referred to as the Interface Hypothesis (IH).

Sorace (2011) summarizes that the interface vulnerability are either explained through representational accounts (e.g. Tsimpli et al., 2004) or processing resources account (e.g. Sorace and Filiaci, 2006). The representational account was proposed by Tsimpli et al. (2004) in a study of first language (L1) attrition of Greek and Italian. The L1–L2 divergence is argued to underlie the attrition effects at the syntax–discourse interface. Hopp (2004) argues that persistent L1 influence underlies L2 learners’ target-deviant behaviours on interfaces in a study of L2 acquisition of German. Montrul (2010) also points out that interfaces are vulnerable to transfer, and it is likely that L1 transfer contributes to the non-convergence of interfaces in the L2 acquisition of Spanish by heritage speakers.

Sorace (2005) and Sorace and Filiaci (2006) suggest that the fated vulnerability of interfaces is due to processing difficulties. The acquisition of interface categories requires not only the relevant syntactic and discourse knowledge but also learners’ ability to integrate the two types of knowledge, which may be beyond L2 learners’ processing resources.

The IH has been tested in simultaneous bilingual development (see, amongst others, Serratrice et al., 2004), L1 attrition (see Tsimpli et al., 2004) and L2 ultimate attainment (see, amongst others, Sorace and Filiaci, 2006). Supporting evidence for the IH has also been reported in L1 attrition and incomplete acquisition of heritage speakers (see, amongst others, Montrul, 2002, 2008; Montrul and Polinsky, 2011) and in L2 development (see, amongst others, Belletti and Leonini, 2004; Pérez-Leroux and Glass, 1999).

Although some work of L2 development is referred to as ‘unwarranted extensions’ of the IH by Sorace (2011), White (2011: 109) points out that there is no reason to assume that L2 learners should not ‘experience similar interface problems to those experienced by bilingual children in the course of their language development, an area encompassed by the IH’. White argues convincingly that interface problems should exist in L2 development and cannot possibly emerge out of the blue in near-native grammars. It is argued that whatever (representation or processing) is difficult at the near-native level will be even more difficult at less proficient levels (Lardiere, 2011; Slabakova, 2008; White, 2011). L2 development should be considered as well as ultimate attainment to fully test the hypothesis that residue problems in L2 acquisition lie in external interfaces exclusively.

The inevitability of fossilization at external interfaces has been questioned by a number of studies (Ivanov, 2009; Iverson et al., 2008; Kraš, 2008; Rothman, 2007, 2009; Slabakova and Ivanov, 2011). Based on different empirical evidence, these studies claim that syntax–discourse interfaces are ultimately acquirable despite possible delays.

In a study of L2 acquisition of the relation between various types of licensing elements and the interpretation of wh-variables as existential polarity words, Yuan (2010) finds that the licensing relation is acquired for some licensors but not for others. He proposes that L2 learners’ success or failure in acquiring interfaces (in particular, the syntax–semantics interface) is not domain-wide. They are likely to be affected by a number of variables, such as ‘the categorical nature of elements involved in the interface relationship, the status of these elements in the target language speakers’ grammar, the input the learners are exposed to, the cross-linguistic influence, etc.’ (p. 258).

The current article presents an empirical study of L2 acquisition of the interpretation of ta ‘he/him’ and the null element in the embedded argument positions by English-speaking learners. I propose that the null element in these positions is not a phonetically null version of ta. Two types of null elements are identified: Øziji and Øtopic. The former is a purely syntactic category, whereas the latter is a syntax–discourse category.

The results provide additional evidence to the claim that grammatical aspects at the syntax–discourse interface are acquirable despite possible developmental delays (e.g. Rothman, 2007, 2009). The article also reports differences between the embedded subject position and the embedded object position regarding the acquisition of Øtopic. L1 transfer and the nature of input may have contributed to the differences in terms of representation and/or processing.

The article is organized as follows. I provide a new analysis for embedded null arguments in Chinese in Section II. Relevant L2 studies are reviewed in Section III. Section IV introduces the current study, whereas Section V discusses the results. Section VI contains a conclusion.

sec.title: II Theoretical background
sec.p: One of the well-noted differences between Chinese and English is that Chinese allows both a null element and an overt pronoun in the subject position of a finite clause and the object position of a transitive verb, whereas English allows the latter but not the former in these positions, as in (1)–(4).

disp-quote.p: (1) Johni says that *e/hei/j likes Tom.
(2) Johni says that Tom likes *e/him i/j.
(3) Xiao Zhangi shuo e i/j/tai/j xihuan Lao Wang.
Xiao Zhang say he like Lao Wang
‘Xiao Zhang says that *e/he likes Lao Wang.’
(4) Xiao Zhangi shuo Lao Wang xihuan e*i/j/tai/j.
Xiao Zhang say Lao Wang like him
‘Xiao Zhang says that Lao Wang likes *e/him.’

sec.p: The English pronoun he/him in (1) and (2) can refer to either the matrix subject John or a discourse entity. Ta and the null element in (3) can both refer to either the matrix subject Xiao Zhang or a discourse entity. Ta in (4) allows both readings, whereas the null element can only refer to a discourse entity. Let us analyse the interpretation of the null elements in (3) and (4) by considering what they are.

The null elements in (3) and (4) have been analysed as pros and variables within the Government and Binding (GB) theory (Huang, 1984). However, it has been noted that the GB proposals of empty categories are incompatible with the Minimalist Program (Holmberg, 2005; Hornstein, 1999; Manzini and Roussou, 2000), and have to be reconsidered.

Roberts (2010) proposes that the phonological silence of a pronoun results from deletion at Phonetic Form (PF). A pronoun deletes from the subject position in Romance null-subject languages such as Italian, as its formal features are a subset of those of its probe T: it is the defective goal of T. Italian differs from English in that the Italian T has a D(efiniteness) feature, whereas the English T does not. The D feature on T makes it possible for the subject pronoun to become its defective goal, as the pronoun intrinsically has a D feature. Roberts postulates that the presence of a D feature on T is associated with rich agreement.

The Chinese null subject cannot be analysed as a deleted pronoun by applying Roberts’ proposal directly. For such an analysis to hold, it would be obligatory to assume that the Chinese T has a D feature like the Italian T. To start with, this assumption is inconsistent with Roberts’ original postulation that the D feature exists on T only in languages with rich verbal inflections. Second, such an assumption cannot explain the subject–object asymmetry in the interpretation of null elements illustrated in (3) and (4) above (see Zhao, 2008).
I propose that one type of Chinese embedded null subject results from deletion of the bare reflexive ziji ‘self’ (hence Øziji). Let us consider this possibility in (5), which is schematized in (6).

disp-quote.p: (5) Zhangsan shuo e renshi Lisi.
Zhangsan say know Lisi
‘Zhangsan says that e knows Lisi.’

sec.p: Chomsky (2008) suggests that only phase heads (i.e. C and v) have phi-features. In some languages such as English, the phi-features of C are transmitted to T. Chomsky further suggests that phi-feature inheritance by T from C is parameterized across languages. Accordingly, I assume that the Chinese C does not transmit its unvalued phi-features to T. C rather than T probes ziji in the embedded clause in (6) and values its case feature as nominative. I assume that ziji is an N-head with unvalued phi-features, which can move from head to head and attach to heads such as C by adjunction during computation (cf. Cole and Sung, 1994; Reinhart and Reuland, 1993). The unvalued φ-features of ziji trigger it to move upwards and head-adjoin to Cembedded. According to the Phase-Impenetrability Condition (PIC) (Chomsky, 2001), C is still accessible to vPmatrix. The matrix subject at Spec-vP is active, as it still has an unvalued case feature. The matrix subject probes ziji and values its unvalued φ-features.1

The crucial thing is that deletion takes place at PF, after the computation of the whole sentence is completed. At PF, ziji has the same phi-features as the matrix subject. Both of them have a nominative case feature. As an N0 category, ziji has a [N] feature. In addition to the [N] feature, the matrix subject has a [D] feature, which is the definiteness feature (Longobardi, 1994; Roberts, 2010). The features of ziji are properly included in those of the matrix subject as in (6). Ziji deletes as a defective goal of the matrix subject in line with Roberts (2010), and Øziji is derived.
An embedded null subject in Chinese can also refer to a discourse entity given proper discourse conditions, as in (7):

disp-quote.p: (7) Q: (Lisii qu guo Lundun ma?)
Lisi go EXP London Q2
‘Has Lisii been to London?’
A: Zhangsan shuo ei qu guo Lundun.
Zhangsan say go EXP London
‘Zhangsan says that ei has been to London.’

sec.p: Given a discourse in the form of a question, the null element in (7A) refers to the discourse prominent Lisi, whereas ziji in the same position cannot. This indicates that there is another type of embedded null subject in Chinese other than Øziji. (7A) is schematized in (8).

Lisi moves from Spec-CPembedded phase by phase until it reaches the outermost Spec-CPmatrix, attracted by the Edge feature of each phase head. Note that the uppermost specifier position is a left edge position for fronted elements, which is different from the specifier position where an external argument originates or moves into (Chomsky, 1995). All the lower copies are suppressed in compliance with chain-reduction (Chomsky, 2001; Nunes, 2004). Chinese allows a Topic NP Deletion Rule (TNPDR), which operates across discourse to delete the topic of a sentence under identity with a topic in a preceding sentence (Huang, 1982, 1984; Tsao, 1977). The result of such a deletion process is a ‘topic chain’. In line with the TNPDR, Lisi in (8) is deleted and (7A) is formed.

We showed above that the embedded subject position allows both Øziji and Øtopic. Below we will look at the embedded object position. The embedded null object in (9) cannot refer to Zhangsan, whereas ziji can. This indicates that the embedded null object cannot be Øziji.

disp-quote.p: (9) Zhangsani shuo Lisi bu renshi e*i/j/zijii/*j.
Zhangsan say Lisi not know
‘Zhangsani says Lisi does not know e*i/j/zijii/*j.’

sec.p: Let us consider why ziji cannot be deleted in the embedded object position. The unvalued φ-features of ziji are valued by the embedded subject Lisi. However, the embedded object ziji can never be a defective goal of Lisi, as the accusative case of the former conflicts with the nominative case of the latter. Therefore, ziji cannot delete.

There is nothing to exclude Øtopic from the embedded object position in Chinese. The embedded object can be topicalized and deleted in accordance with the TNPDR. When this happens, we have an embedded null object referring to a discourse entity, as in (10A) below.

disp-quote.p: (10) Q: Lisi renshi Lao Wangi ma?
Lisi know Lao Wang Q
‘Does Lisi know Lao Wangi?’
A: Zhangsan shuo Lisi bu renshi ei.
Zhangsan say Lisi not know
* ‘Zhangsan says Lisi does not know ei.’

sec.p: English does not have bare reflexives, let alone Øziji. English does not allow the TNPDR, which is crucial to the derivation of Øtopic. Therefore, Øtopic does not exist in English.

The English he/him and the Chinese ta are both D-pronouns in terms of Noguchi (1997), which can refer to either the matrix subject – referential as in (3) above or quantified as in (11) below – or a discourse entity.

disp-quote.p: (11) Meigereni dou shuo tai/j mingtian yao lai.
everyone all say he tomorrow want come
‘Everyonei says that he i/j wants to come tomorrow.’

sec.title: III L2 acquisition of overt and null arguments: Existing studies
sec.p: The interpretation of overt and covert embedded subjects has been investigated in Spanish (Lozano, 2003; Pérez-Leroux and Glass, 1997, 1999) and Japanese (Kanno, 1997; Marsden, 1998). An important focus of these studies is the acquisition of the Overt Pronoun Constraint (OPC): i.e. the overt pronoun can take a referential matrix subject as a possible antecedent but not a quantified one. Treated as a universal principle, the OPC is used to test Universal Grammar access in second language acquisition in these studies. Several subsequent studies raise doubts about the universality of the OPC (Gürel, 2002; Ojima, 2004; Yamada, 2005). These studies indicate that the overt pronoun in an embedded argument position cannot refer to the matrix subject in Turkish or Japanese, whereas the null element can, whether the matrix subject is quantified or referential. The null element in these studies is analysed as pro. The interpretation of the overt pronoun and pro in native grammars and L2 grammars are explained through parameterized governing categories or Distributed Morphology. I note that the OPC does not hold in Chinese. Like the English he, the Chinese pronoun ta can refer to both a referential matrix subject (as in (3)) and a quantified matrix subject (as in (11)). This makes Chinese different from the languages discussed in the studies above. The distinction between the referential matrix subject and the quantified one is not important to the L2 study of the interpretation of ta and the null element in Chinese. Most of the studies above only research the subject position except for Yamada (2005). Nonetheless, the subject–object asymmetry in Chinese noted in this article is not reported in Yamada’s study. I will not introduce these studies in detail here, as they do not inform the current study directly.

Yuan (1993) researches if null arguments are allowed in L2 Chinese grammars of English speakers at different states through an Acceptability Judgment task. The results indicate that English-speaking learners accept both null subjects and null objects from a very early stage onwards.

sec.title: 1 Research questions and hypotheses
sec.p: To the best of my knowledge, there is no study investigating if overt and covert arguments are properly represented and interpreted in L2 Chinese. This study aims to go some way in addressing this lacuna. It focuses on the embedded argument positions. In line with the proposal in Section II, null elements in these positions are either Øziji or Øtopic. With Øziji being a purely syntactic category, Øtopic involving syntax–discourse external interface and the interpretation of ta involving lexicon–syntax and syntax–semantics internal interfaces, it is an interesting study for the IH. Specifically, this article intends to answer the following questions:

list-item.p: Can English-speaking L2 learners interpret ta in the embedded argument positions in the same way as native Chinese speakers?
Can they acquire Øziji as a defective goal?
Can they acquire Øtopic and represent it as deletion of the topicalized subject/object under identity with the chain topic of the topic chain (i.e. as a piece of old information in the discourse)?

sec.p: The Chinese ta is a D-pronoun that can refer to either the matrix subject or the discourse entity. Such interpretation results from the lexical–syntactic structure of ta. The study is not concerned with any pragmatic constraint for the interpretation of ta. Therefore, its interpretation does not involve external interfaces here (Tsoulas and Gil, 2011). At most it involves lexicon–syntax and syntax–semantics internal interfaces. According to the IH, internal interfaces are acquirable. English-speaking learners are expected to have no problem interpreting ta.

Null pronouns are syntactically impossible in Chinese. L2 learners are expected to acquire this purely syntactic knowledge. Similarly, Øziji is expected to be acquirable, as its derivation is purely syntactic.

An important prediction of the IH is that the syntax–discourse interface categories may never be completely acquired by L2 learners. If this prediction holds, Øtopic should be subject to incomplete acquisition, because its derivation involves the syntactic computation of topicalization as well as the discourse notion of topic chain and thus is a syntax–discourse interface category. The acquisition of Øziji and the incomplete acquisition of Øtopic should hold true of both the embedded subject position and the embedded object position.

sec.title: 2 Participants
sec.p: Thirty-nine English-speaking learners and 16 native speakers of Chinese participated in the experiment. None of the native speakers had a high level of English proficiency. English-speaking learners were chosen for the following reasons. The English he/him and the Chinese ta can both refer to the matrix subject and a discourse entity due to its lexical–syntactic structure. If the IH about internal interfaces holds, English-speaking learners will have no problem interpreting ta in a native-like manner. If it is not borne out, they will not interpret ta correctly despite the similarity between English and Chinese in this regard. Unlike Chinese, English does not allow null elements in the sentence positions under investigation. With Øziji belonging to pure syntax and Øtopic to the syntax–discourse interface, it is interesting to see if both are acquirable by English-speaking learners. The learners were mainly from universities in Beijing, attending Mandarin Chinese programmes. All the L2 learners started learning Chinese in a non-Chinese environment and had spent a certain period in China by the time of the experiment. They were divided into two groups based on the results of a cloze test: high-intermediate (HI) and advanced (AD). Detailed information on each group is presented in Table 1. A one-way ANOVA test reveals significant group effects in terms of proficiency (F(2, 52) = 153.878, p < 0.001). Post-hoc Games–Howell tests show that the learner groups differ significantly from each other and from the native Chinese group. Although the IH was proposed with near-native L2 speakers in mind, it has been argued above that L2 development should also be considered to fully test the hypothesis that long-term and residue problems of L2 learners exclusively lie in external interfaces.

caption.p: Information about subjects in each group

tr.th: Average number of months learning Chinese
Average number of months in mainland China/Taiwan
Mean scores in the cloze test (n = 40)

sec.title: 3 Materials
sec.p: The participants were required to complete three tasks: a proficiency cloze test, a written interpretation task (WIT) and a picture judgment task (PJT). Although the results from the WIT are not reported, it is worth noting that they are generally consistent with those from the PJT.

The PJT consisted of 36 context-providing pictures, each accompanied by four sentences to be marked on a scale ranging from –2 to 2 (from ‘completely untrue to the picture’ to ‘completely true to the picture’). The option ‘I don’t know’ was used in place of the number ‘0’ on the scale, for the consideration that ‘0’ might cause confusion between ‘I don’t know’ and ‘neither good nor bad’ (White, 2003). An option ‘incorrect sentence’ was also included. The participants were instructed to choose this option if they thought the sentence was unacceptable. It was useful in detecting if a subject accepted the use of null elements in the embedded argument position. If null elements were not even accepted, their interpretation was out of the question. According to Yuan (1993), L2 learners allow null arguments from a very early stage onwards. This option only served as a precaution. As reported in the following section, it was rarely chosen.

Among the 36 pictures, 12 were concerned with the current study. Two types of pictures were designed: One illustrated a situation in which the embedded argument referred to the matrix subject (termed ‘coreferential pictures’, as in Figure 2); the other type illustrated a situation in which the embedded argument referred to someone other than the matrix subject (termed ‘disjoint pictures’, as in Figure 1). The study reported here was part of a larger-scale study. There were a balanced number of coreferential and disjoint pictures in the task. The number of appropriate and inappropriate sentences was also balanced in the task. Both the pictures and sentences were randomized.

Two of the four sentences accompanying these pictures were test sentences, one of which has a null element in the embedded argument position, whereas the other one has ta. The other two sentences were distractors for the current study. Some of them had ziji in the embedded argument position. Some were simply wrong descriptions of the picture. This article will analyse eight sentence types (as in Table 2), each having three tokens. These eight sentence types were formed through the interaction of the following variables: sentence position (subject vs. object); NP type: (ta vs. null element); and reading (i.e. the type of picture: coref vs. disj). Test sentences accompanying a coreferential picture were either the same with or minimally different from those accompanying the corresponding disjoint picture. At the most, the differences between them were the names of the cartoon figures, which were given in the pictures in both English and Chinese, as shown in the sentences accompanying Figures 1 and 2.

caption.p: Types of sentences in the picture judgement task

tr.td: The picture depicts a situation where ta in the embedded subject position needs to be coreferential with the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where ta in the embedded subject position needs to refer to an entity other than the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where the embedded null subject needs to be coreferential with the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where the embedded null subject needs to refer to an entity other than the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where ta in the embedded object position needs to be coreferential with the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where ta in the embedded object position needs to refer to an entity other than the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where the embedded null object needs to be coreferential with the matrix subject.
The picture depicts a situation where the embedded null object needs to refer to an entity other than the matrix subject.

sec.title: 4 Results
sec.p: Table 3 presents the mean scores of each group by sentence type. The score ‘+1’ and above are taken as acceptance, and ‘–1’ and below as rejection. The ‘incorrect sentence’ and the ‘I don’t know’ options were very rarely chosen by learners at all states. This is consistent with Yuan’s (1993) finding that English-speaking learners allow null arguments from a very early state onwards.

caption.p: Mean scores of L2 learners and controls

fn.p: Note: * significantly different from the native speakers’ group

sec.p: I will analyse the data from the subject position and the object position respectively to see if learners acquire the interpretation of ta and the null element in different sentence positions. I will also analyse the data of the coreferential null element and the disjoint null element respectively with sentence position as a variable to see if interfacing with discourse is the sole reason for incomplete acquisition of Øtopic, and if purely syntactic knowledge is acquirable as predicted. The sentence position should not matter in either case if IH holds.

sec.title: a The subject position:
sec.p: A factorial ANOVA with repeated-measures comparing NP type and reading by group shows significant effects for group (F(2, 52) = 6.204, p = .004); NP type (F(1, 52) = 31.532, p < .001), with higher scores for ta than the null element regarding the disjoint reading and similar scores for the two regarding the coreferential reading; and reading (F(1, 52) = 9.371, p = .003), with higher score for the coreferential reading than the disjoint reading regarding the null element and similar scores for the two regarding ta. Pairwise comparisons reveal that native speakers’ responses are significantly different from the high-intermediate learners, but not from the advanced learners. There are also significant interactions between NP type and group (F(2, 52) = 5.578, p = .006), reading and group (F(2,52) = 2.199, p = .010), NP type and reading (F(1, 51) = 26.948; p < .001) and between NP type, reading and group (F(2, 52) = 6.295; p = .004).

The results indicate that the high-intermediate group interpret ta and the null element in a significantly different way from the native speakers, whereas the advanced learners interpret them in a native-like way. Table 3 shows that both L2 groups correctly interpret ta as referring to either the matrix subject or someone else. They have no problem interpreting the embedded null subject as referring to the matrix subject. The lack of difference between the learner groups and the NS (native speaker) group regarding the readings of ta and the coreferential reading of the null element is confirmed statistically by one-way ANOVA tests. Although L2 learners do not distinguish ta and the null element regarding the coreferential reading, they do so regarding the disjoint reading at the HI state. The difference between HI and NS noted above seems to lie in the disjoint reading of the null element. A one-way ANOVA test yields significant group effects (F(4, 86) = 7.410, p < .001) for Type Subj+disj Null, with post-hoc Tukey tests revealing a significant difference between NS and HI. The results indicate that learners do not acquire native-like competence until the advanced state in allowing an embedded null subject to refer to a discourse entity.

This is supported by individual results. I follow Akiyama (2002) in assuming that consistency can be postulated if there are two acceptances/rejections out of three. Following Thomas (1989) and Lin (2009), I classify the answers in the following way. A participant is considered to exhibit ‘full acceptance’ if he or she accepts all three test sentences, or ‘partial acceptance’ if he or she accepts two. The other patterns are classified as ‘no acceptance’. Table 4 shows that over half of the HI learners show ‘no acceptance’. The HI group does not perform at a native-like level in accepting the disjoint reading of the embedded null subject. By contrast, the majority of the advanced learners consistently accept it.

caption.p: Individual results for Subj+disj Null (percentages in parentheses)

sec.title: b The object position
sec.p: A repeated-measures ANOVA test reveals significant main effects for group (F(2, 52) = 4.264, p = .019); NP type (F(1, 52) = 207.547, p < .001), with higher scores for ta than the null element regarding the coreferential reading and similar scores for the two regarding the disjoint reading; and reading (F(1, 52) = 126.167, p < .001), with higher scores for the disjoint reading than the coreferential reading regarding the null element and similar scores for the two regarding ta. Pairwise comparisons indicate that native speakers’ responses are significantly different from the high-intermediate learners’ (p = .001), but not from the advanced learners’. Interactions between NP type and group, reading and group, NP type and reading, and between NP type, reading and group also reach significance (p < .001 for all the interactions).

The above results indicate that the three groups distinguish the interpretations of the null element and ta differently. The HI learners differentiate their interpretations in a way different from the other two groups. Table 3 shows that the HI learners, like the AD learners and the native speakers, allow ta to refer to the matrix subject or a discourse entity. All the three groups allow the null element to refer to a discourse entity. In particular, 84.6% of the L2 learners (i.e. 22 out of 26) consistently allow the disjoint reading of the embedded null object at the HI state already. One-way ANOVAs tests produce no significant difference between the three groups on Type Obj+coref ta, Obj+disj ta or Obj+disj Null.

The HI group differs from the other groups concerning the coreferential reading of the null element. A one-way ANOVA test reveals significant group effects for Type *Obj+coref Null (F(2, 52) = 21.836, p < .001), with group differences found between HI and AD, HI and NS, and also between AD and NS. As shown in Table 5, the ‘no rejection’ rate is 69.2% among HI learners, whereas 84.6% of the advanced learners consistently reject this type of sentence. The native speakers unanimously reject it. These results indicate that learners have improved significantly in rejecting the coreferential reading of the embedded null object by the AD state, although they are still not as confident as the native speakers.

caption.p: Individual results for *Obj+coref Null (percentages in parentheses)

sec.title: c The disjoint reading of the null element:
sec.p: A repeated-measures ANOVA test produces significant main effects of group (F(2, 52) = 6.140, p = .004) and sentence position (F(1, 52) = 17.131, p < .001), with higher scores for the object position than the subject position. Pairwise comparisons show a significant difference between the HI group and the NS group. Individual analyses indicate that the HI learners who consistently accept the disjoint reading of the embedded subject also consistently accept that of the embedded object, but not vice versa. The interaction between position and group also reaches significance (F(2, 52) = 6.140, p = .004).

The results indicate that the sentence position variable figures prominently in the acquisition of Øtopic. Øtopic is acquired earlier in the embedded object position than in the embedded subject position.

sec.title: d The coreferential reading of the null element:
sec.p: A repeated-measures ANOVA test reveals significant main effects of group (F(2, 52) = 11.715, p < .001) and sentence position (F(1, 52) = 250.070, p < .001), with higher scores for the subject position than the object position. Pairwise comparisons indicate that the HI group is significantly different from the NS group. The interaction between group and position is also significant (F(2, 52) = 23.971, p < .001).

The results indicate that the sentence position variable plays an important role in the acquisition of the coreferential reading of the null element. Combined with the results from Table 3, the results show that it is easier for L2 learners to accept it in the embedded subject position than to reject it in the embedded object position.

sec.title: V Discussion
sec.p: As shown in Table 6, ta and a null element allow the same readings only in the embedded subject position in native and advanced L2 grammars. They are interpreted differently in the embedded subject position by HI learners, and in the embedded object position by learners at both states and native speakers.

caption.p: A brief summary of the findings

sec.p: The hypothesis made in line with the IH is borne out for the interpretation of ta. L2 learners do not have any problem interpreting ta correctly. The interpretation of ta tested here stems from the D-pronoun nature. At the most it involves lexicon–syntax and syntax–semantics interfaces (Tsoulas and Gil, 2011). It does not involve external interfaces, as no pragmatic constraint is concerned. It is also possible that transfer plays a positive role here, as ta is a D-pronoun like he/him in learners’ native language.

L2 learners do not have any problem relating the embedded null subject to the matrix subject. It is argued in Section II that the Chinese embedded null subject that refers to the matrix subject results from deletion of ziji as a defective goal of the matrix subject. It is possible that learners correctly represent Øziji in the embedded subject position from the HI state onwards. However, we cannot deny the possibility that learners may perceive the embedded null subject as a phonetically null equivalent of an English pronoun. If this is the case, we have no clear evidence to show the state at which the coreferential embedded null subject is represented as Øziji. As argued later, it is possible that learners are not fully aware until the advanced state that null pronouns are not allowed in Chinese. Then it is likely that only advanced learners correctly represent the coreferential embedded null subject as Øziji. In either case, the data support the IH that purely syntactic knowledge is acquirable. As argued in Section II, null pronouns are syntactically impossible. In addition, Øziji is a purely syntactic category. We may make the following assumption of the representation of embedded Øziji subject at least in advanced L2 Chinese grammars in line with my proposal in Section II. The bare reflexive ziji with unvalued φ-features moves and head-adjoins to C to have its φ-features valued. Its φ-features are valued at C by agreeing with the matrix subject. At PF, the features of ziji constitute a subset of those of the matrix subject and thus ziji is phonetically suppressed.

I argued in Section II that Øtopic contributes to the disjoint reading of the embedded null subject. This type of null element is derived from the deletion of a topicalized embedded subject under identity with the chain topic of the topic chain. As its derivation involves both the syntactic computation and the discourse notion of topic chain, it is a syntax–discourse interface category and is hypothesized to be vulnerable to fossilisation according to the IH. This hypothesis is not supported by the data here: The L2 learners successfully take a discourse entity as the referent of the embedded null subject at the advanced state. However, they fail to do so at the HI state. This supports the claim that syntax–discourse interfaces may be prone to delays but they are ultimately acquirable (see, amongst others, Rothman, 2007, 2009; Slabakova and Ivanov, 2011).

In line with Sorace (2011), there may be two accounts for the difficulties L2 learners have with Øtopic: the processing resources account and the representational account. Sorace and Filiaci (2006) propose that the acquisition of interface categories requires not only the relevant syntactic and discourse knowledge but also learners’ ability to coordinate the two. Thus it may be argued that it is too demanding in terms of processing for high-intermediate learners to integrate the syntactic computations of the sentence and the discourse knowledge of the topic chain. I will come back to a possible representational account later.

L2 learners do not correctly reject the coreferential reading of the embedded null object until the advanced state. L2 learners may have considered the embedded null object as a null ziji or ta at earlier states (for details, see Zhao, 2008). At the HI state, L2 learners are still in the process of acquiring the knowledge that a null ziji or ta is not allowed in the embedded object position, resulting in the optionality. I argued in Section II that case clash rules out the possibility of Øziji in the embedded object position. Null pronouns are not allowed in Chinese, as Chinese T/v does not have a D feature. Thus the disallowance of Øziji or null pronouns here is due to purely syntactic reasons. The fact that L2 learners eventually reject the coreferential reading of the embedded null object are consistent with the IH that pure syntax is acquirable.

Learners allow the embedded null object to refer to a discourse entity at both HI and AD states. This shows that learners have acquired Øtopic in the embedded object position by the HI state. As discussed above, Øtopic is not acquired in the embedded subject position until the advanced state. The fact that Øtopic as a syntax–discourse interface category is eventually acquired in both positions supports Yuan’s (2010) claim that problems with interface categories may not be domain-wide. More importantly, sentence position is an important factor in the acquisition of Øtopic. It is acquired later in the subject position than in the object position. Why is this so? The processing account alone as proposed above obviously cannot account for this, as the processing of Øtopic involves the integration of multiple types of information in both positions. I argue below that the divergence between the two positions further supports Yuan’s (2010) claim that interface vulnerability may not be domain-wide. Rather, we need to consider different variables, such as crosslinguistic influence and input. In this case, we even need to take a variable-dependent approach in dealing with the same interface category.

As proposed in Section II, Øtopic is derived from deletion of the topicalized element as a piece of old information in the discourse in compliance with TNPDR. In this sense, the successful representation of Øtopic takes topicalization and TNPDR as two prerequisites. The derivational difference of Øtopic in the two positions lies in the element that is topicalized: the embedded subject vs. the embedded object.
Both English and Chinese allow the topicalization of the embedded object, as in (12).

disp-quote.p: (12) a. Jeff, Tom thinks that Lee knows.
b. Zhangsan, Lisi yiwei Wangwu renshi.
Zhangsan Lisi thinks Wangwu know
Zhangsan, Lisi thinks that Wangwu knows.

sec.p: By contrast, Chinese diverges from English regarding subject topicalization. Chinese allows the matrix subject Zhangsan to be topicalized as in (13a), whereas the topicalization of John crashes the English sentence in (13b). This difference between English and Chinese can be explained in line with Rizzi and Shlonsky (2007), who propose that an element cannot be moved out once it has been moved to the subject position (i.e. Spec- TP in the framework adopted in this article) during computation. As assumed in this article, the Chinese subject moves to a position (i.e. Spec-CP) other than the usual subject position and thus allows subject topicalization. This is also true with Chinese embedded subjects, as in (13c).

disp-quote.p: (13) a. Zhangsan, e shi ge hao haizi.
Zhangsan be CL good child
* ‘Zhangsan, e is a good child.’
b. * John, e is a good child.
c. Xiao Zhang, Lao Wang shuo e xihuan Lisi.
Xiao Zhang Lao Wang say like Lisi
‘Xiao Zhang, Lao Wang says that e likes Lisi.’

sec.p: The that-trace effect exists in the topicalization of English embedded subjects. The embedded subject can only be topicalized when there is no complementizer that, as in (14). Zhao (2008) argues that the embedded subject moves to Spec-CP when that does not exist. It moves to Spec-TP otherwise, where it gets frozen.

disp-quote.p: (14) a. * Lee, Tom thinks that e knows Jeff.
b. Lee, Tom thinks e knows Jeff.

sec.p: The comparison between English and Chinese regarding topicalization points to a possibility that crosslinguistic influence may have contributed to the difference between the subject position and the object position in the acquisition of Øtopic.

It is possible that L1 transfer may have positively influenced L2 grammars in terms of the embedded object topicalization. Consequently, L2 learners allow the topicalization of the embedded object from the very beginning. This speculation is supported by Yao (2007), who finds that English-speaking learners are aware that an embedded object in Chinese can be topicalized as early as the beginners’ state.

In comparison with object topicalization, the influence L2 learners possibly get from their native language is more complex and thus may be more confusing regarding subject topicalization. An English subject moves from Spec-vP to Spec-TP, and thus cannot be topicalized either when it appears in a matrix clause or when it appears in an embedded clause with the complementizer that. An English subject moves from Spec-vP to Spec-CP, and can be topicalized only when it appears in an embedded clause without that. In this sense, the Spec-vP to Spec-CP movement prevalent in the target language is restricted in learners’ native language. It may be possible that learners initially only move the subject from Spec-vP to Spec-TP, and this is not fully expunged until the advanced state. This is possibly due to L1 transfer, as the Spec-vP to Spec-TP movement exists in English, but not in Chinese. However, restricted as it is, the Spec-vP to Spec-CP movement exists in English. It is not clear why this type of movement is not transferred to L2 Chinese grammars. Alternatively, the Spec-vP to Spec-TP movement of the embedded subject may be a developmental stage that all L2 learners of Chinese go through. Learners of different language origins need to be tested in order to see if this assumption holds. The Spec-TP position freezes the subject, and further extraction becomes impossible (Rizzi and Shlonsky, 2007). Therefore, learners may initially disallow the topicalization of the embedded subject, which leads to delay in their acquisition of Øtopic in the embedded subject position.

Processing difficulties may also contribute to the later acquisition of Øtopic in the embedded subject position. Even after learners become aware that the Chinese subject occupies Spec-CP, they may be still faced with added difficulty in processing Øtopic in this position, as they need to integrate a newly established syntactic derivation and discourse information. By contrast, the acquisition of Øtopic in the embedded object position requires the integration of discourse information and syntactic derivation that is acquired early due to positive L1 transfer. It is not surprising that Øtopic is easier to acquire in the embedded object position than in the embedded subject position.

I argued above that crosslinguistic difference may have contributed to the representational and/or processing difficulties of Øtopic in the embedded subject position. Below I argue that the nature of input may be another factor that causes the delay.

Two types of positive evidence may possibly trigger the awareness of subject movement from Spec-vP to Spec-CP. First, learners may notice that matrix subjects can be topicalized in Chinese – as in (13a) above – which may trigger learners to become aware that the matrix subject is not in Spec-TP in Chinese. Second, the following evidence may also serve as a trigger. Unlike English, Chinese allows complex reflexives to appear in embedded subject positions, as in (15):

disp-quote.p: (15) Zhangsan renwei taziji shi ge tiancai.
Zhangsan think himself be CL genius
* ‘Zhangsan thinks that himself is a genius.’

sec.p: The word taziji ‘himself’ in (15) refers to the matrix subject Zhangsan. Chomsky (2008) suggests that the Binding Principle A can be explained as a case of Agree. Although I do not go into details about Agree between Zhangsan and taziji, I argue that in order for Zhangsan to probe taziji, the latter has to be seen by the former; taziji cannot be seen by Zhangsan if it is at Spec-TP. It can be seen only if it is at Spec-CP according to the PIC. It is possible that the use of taziji in the embedded subject position may provide positive evidence that the Chinese subject moves from Spec-vP to Spec-CP.

Neither the topicalization of matrix subjects nor the use of complex reflexives in embedded subject positions appears very frequently in Chinese. In addition, the topicalized matrix subjects can be easily mistaken for subjects. In written Chinese, although a comma as in (13a) above or a topic marker such as a in (16) below can be used to mark Zhangsan as a topic, not all topics are followed by them. In spoken Chinese, some Chinese speakers use a pause or a topic marker to mark the topic of the sentence. Nonetheless, not everybody does so. Even when a pause or topic marker is used, learners may not be able to detect it, because of its subtlety or its lack of phonological prominence.

disp-quote.p: (16) Zhangsani a, ei shi ge laoshi.
Zhangsan TOP be CL teacher
‘Zhangsani, ei is a teacher.’

sec.p: Carroll’s (1999) proposes that adult L2 learners are not equally sensitive to every type of evidence in the input from the beginning (see also Yuan, 2007). Not all cues are ‘good’ cues for the L2 acquisition mechanism at a particular state. Input needs to be differentiated from intake (Corder, 1967). Carroll (2001) proposes that intake is contingent on L2 grammars. Learners’ perception of the target language is constrained not only by their conceptual models of the environment, but also by their linguistic systems. L2 language forms cannot be acquired unless they are noticed (Schmidt, 1993). Although the above positive evidence exists from the very beginning, L2 grammars may not be sophisticated enough to allow learners to perceive or perceive enough of it to fully expunge their initial grammars until the advanced state.

sec.title: VI Conclusions
sec.p: The current study has shown that while purely syntactic categories such as Øziji and the internal interfaces such as the interpretation of ta are acquirable, some syntax–discourse external interface categories such as Øtopic are also acquirable, contra the IH. The findings are consistent with those of Ivanov, 2009; Iverson et al., 2008; Kraš, 2008; Rothman, 2007, 2009; Slabakova and Ivanov, 2011. Øtopic is acquired earlier in the embedded object position than in the embedded subject position. This study provides supporting evidence to Yuan’s (2010) claim that the interfaces should not be treated holistically, and that variables such as L1 transfer and input should be considered in their acquisition. Empirically, it finds that ta and the covert element do not always share the same meaning in embedded argument positions in either the native Chinese grammar or English-speaking learners’ L2 grammars.

Although the present study provides some useful data regarding the acquisition of interpretation of overt and covert arguments in Chinese, a number of issues have to be investigated further in order to gain a deeper insight. The acquisition of the null elements can be further investigated by including more sentence positions, such as matrix argument positions. The current study only includes English-speaking learners, whose L1 does not allow null elements in the subject position of a finite clause or the object position. Future research might include L2 learners whose L1 allows null elements in these positions, for a deeper understanding about developmental problems and L1 transfer in this respect.

fn.p: I assume probing to be ‘blind’ and therefore potentially unsuccessful from the probe’s perspective, with some Agree operations only resulting in valuation of features on the goal (cf. Hicks, 2006; Landau, 2000).
The abbreviations used in the gloss in this article are EXP = experiential aspect marker; Q = yes–no question particle; PFV = perfective aspect marker; CL = classifier; TOP = topic marker.
